alt_statements.statement: As someone who’s spent a career in public education and community work, I’ve seen that environmental protection and economic growth don’t have to be at odds if we plan thoughtfully and invest in people. Climate policy should put environmental sustainability first—because without a stable climate, long-term economic health is impossible—but it should also channel funding into green jobs, local infrastructure, and school-based programs that help workers and communities transition. In my view, the right balance is to treat environmental limits as non-negotiable guardrails and then drive innovation, training, and economic development within those boundaries so we leave a healthier, more resilient economy for the next generation.

As a high school English teacher and a motherly figure to many of my students, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because there’s no real “economy” on a planet whose systems are breaking down. That said, we should focus on policies that create good, stable green jobs—especially in public infrastructure and education—so that working families and local communities aren’t asked to shoulder all the sacrifices. To me, the right balance is ambitious climate action paired with strong support for workers and vulnerable communities, not using economic growth as an excuse to delay doing what we know is necessary.

We need a commonsense balance where we protect the environment without strangling the very economy that puts food on the table. I’ve worked with my hands my whole life, and I’ve seen how overregulation can kill good-paying jobs, so climate policy should focus on practical steps—like improving efficiency, supporting innovation, and using cleaner energy—without punishing workers or driving up costs for families. I believe we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but that stewardship has to respect people’s livelihoods and our need for reliable, affordable energy.

As a restaurant manager who’s seen firsthand how rising food costs and climate impacts hit both small businesses and workers, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and protect ecosystems, while investing in clean energy, resilient agriculture, and green jobs so that working people and local businesses aren’t left behind. We should prioritize long-term health—of people and the planet—over short-term profit, with strong regulations on major polluters and targeted support for communities and industries that need to transition.

As someone who spends a lot of time outdoors watching birds, I see firsthand how fragile ecosystems are and how quickly habitats can vanish, so I believe environmental protection has to lead climate policy, not trail behind economic interests. That said, I work in retail and understand people need stable jobs, so the smart path is investing aggressively in clean energy and green infrastructure that create good-paying jobs while cutting emissions. We shouldn't accept the old idea that you have to wreck the environment to grow the economy—long-term prosperity depends on a stable climate and healthy natural world.

As someone who runs a nonprofit and sees firsthand how policy choices shape real lives, I don’t accept the idea that we have to choose between environmental protection and economic growth. Smart climate policy can drive innovation, create good jobs, and strengthen communities—especially if we invest in clean energy, modern infrastructure, and worker retraining. We should put strong environmental safeguards in place and design economic strategies around them, not treat them as an afterthought, because a healthy economy ultimately depends on a healthy planet.

Given what I see in my work, I don’t buy the idea that environmental protection and economic growth are opposites—climate disasters are already incredibly expensive, and they’re only going to get worse if we don’t act. Climate policy should prioritize aggressive emissions reductions and resilience measures, even if that means short‑term costs, because the long‑term economic and human toll of inaction is far higher. The right balance is to set strong, science-based environmental standards and then give businesses clear, stable rules and incentives to innovate within that framework.

As a medical research scientist, I see climate policy first and foremost as a public health intervention: environmental degradation directly drives disease, strain on healthcare systems, and long‑term economic instability. Economic growth that depends on high emissions is, biologically speaking, a short‑lived gain with severe downstream costs, so our priority should be aggressive emissions reductions and ecosystem protection, paired with targeted investment in green industries and worker retraining. In other words, we shouldn’t be trading health for GDP; we should be redefining growth so that clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and low‑carbon innovation are the engines of a healthier, more sustainable economy.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of the world we leave our children, and it isn’t pretty. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with economic growth reshaped around clean energy, conservation, and green jobs rather than fossil fuels and waste. We’re creative enough as a society to build an economy that thrives without destroying creation, and government has a moral responsibility—one I see as deeply Catholic—to protect the most vulnerable people and ecosystems from climate harm.

Having spent a career in finance and now devoting my time to environmental work, I’m convinced that framing climate policy as a tug-of-war between the economy and the environment is outdated and dangerous. We should prioritize strong environmental protections and aggressive decarbonization, and use smart market design, regulation, and public investment to drive innovation and create good jobs in the process. The real economic risk isn’t from bold climate action, but from clinging to a carbon-heavy status quo that will leave communities, markets, and ecosystems far more unstable in the long run.

As someone who cares a lot about the future I’m going to live in, I don’t think environmental protection and economic growth should be treated as competing goals—real long‑term growth depends on a livable planet. Climate policy should aggressively cut emissions and invest in clean energy, green infrastructure, and environmental justice, especially for communities of color that are often hit first and worst by climate impacts. I’d rather see us accept short‑term economic adjustments than keep propping up fossil fuels and pass the real costs—stronger storms, health problems, and instability—onto my generation.

As someone raising kids on a modest income and working in a public school, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, but we’ve got to stop pretending that short-term profits are worth wrecking the planet my children have to live in. Climate policy should invest in clean energy, public transit, and weatherization in ways that create good local jobs, especially in communities like mine, so working families aren’t asked to choose between a paycheck and clean air and water.

We need to protect the land and water God gave us, but we also have to be realistic about people’s livelihoods and the cost of living. Climate policy should focus on practical measures that don’t destroy jobs or make energy unaffordable for working people and seniors on fixed incomes. I support gradual, market-based solutions and better technology, not heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses and raise everyone’s bills.

As a cop and a dad, I want my kids growing up in a world where the air’s clean and the weather’s not getting more dangerous every year, but I also know families around here depend on steady jobs and affordable living. We should push hard on clean energy, public transit, and efficiency standards, not just because it’s good for the planet, but because it can create stable, middle‑class jobs and reduce long‑term costs from disasters and health problems. To me, the right balance is setting strong environmental rules and timelines, then backing workers and small businesses with training, incentives, and support so they’re not left behind in the transition. That way we’re protecting both public safety and economic security, instead of pretending we have to sacrifice one for the other.

My mamá and papá tell me that we have to take care of “la tierrita” God gave us, so I think protecting the environment should come first, especially for kids like me who will live here a long time. But I also know my family works hard and money can be tight, so climate policies should help people get good jobs in clean energy and not make it harder for families to afford what they need. If we’re careful and smart, we can have both clean air and water and a strong, fair economy for everyone.

As someone who runs restaurants and depends on a strong economy, I think climate policy has to protect the environment without crushing the businesses that keep people employed and communities vibrant. We should push for practical, science-based measures—like incentives for energy-efficient equipment, reducing food waste, and cleaner supply chains—so that going green actually saves money over time instead of just adding costs. Hard work and innovation can turn environmental responsibility into a competitive advantage, but regulations need to be realistic and phased in so small and mid-sized businesses can adapt. From my Catholic perspective, we have a moral duty to care for creation, but also to protect people’s livelihoods, so the right balance is policies that drive gradual, steady change rather than abrupt shocks to the economy.

Coming from Colorado and working in education-focused tours, I see firsthand how much local economies depend on natural beauty—and how fragile that is if we don’t protect the environment. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with strong regulations and investments in clean energy and green jobs, because long-term economic growth depends on a stable climate and healthy ecosystems. We can’t treat it like a trade-off between the planet and paychecks; smart policy can do both, but it has to start by respecting environmental limits.

As a science teacher, a mom, and an immigrant who’s seen smog-choked cities and clear mountain air, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection as optional or secondary to economic growth—our kids’ futures depend on a livable planet. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, green infrastructure, and public transit, not just to cut emissions but to create stable, well-paying jobs and healthier communities. Economic growth that destroys the climate is fake prosperity; real progress is building an economy that lifts people up while shrinking our carbon footprint.

As a Christian and a father, I believe we are called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but also to provide for our families and communities in a responsible way. Climate policy should protect the environment without crippling jobs, small businesses, or the ability of churches and charities to serve those in need. We should focus on practical, affordable solutions—like cleaner technologies, energy efficiency, and local conservation efforts—rather than sweeping regulations that hit working families the hardest. In all things, we must seek a balance that honors God’s creation while respecting the dignity of work and economic opportunity.

At my age, looking back over decades of teaching history, it’s clear that societies that chew through their natural resources for short-term gain always pay a higher price later. We ought to treat environmental protection as the foundation of long-term economic health, not an obstacle to it—investing in clean energy, conservation, and green infrastructure can create good jobs while preserving a livable planet for our grandchildren. As a progressive and a Catholic, I see this as both prudent public policy and a moral obligation to safeguard creation and care for the most vulnerable, who suffer first and worst from climate change.

As a public school teacher and a Democrat who cares deeply about future generations, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first while still providing a just, realistic path for economic growth. We should be investing aggressively in green infrastructure, clean energy, and climate-resilient jobs, especially in communities that are most vulnerable, so that we’re not choosing between a livable planet and people’s livelihoods. From both my Jewish values around stewardship and justice and my experience seeing how policy shapes kids’ futures, I believe the real measure of “growth” should be whether it leaves our students a safer, more equitable world.

As someone who does hands-on work in buildings every day, I see how much energy we waste and how small changes—better insulation, smarter lighting, efficient systems—can cut costs and pollution at the same time. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; smart climate policy can create good, stable jobs, especially in building retrofits and green infrastructure, while protecting the communities we live in. As a liberal Democrat and a Jew, I feel a moral responsibility to care for the earth and for vulnerable people who’ll be hit hardest by climate change. So I support aggressive climate action that invests in clean technology, worker protections, and community-based programs, even if it means short-term costs for long-term justice and prosperity.

I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so it protects the land and air we all depend on, without crushing the folks who actually keep the economy moving. As a truck driver, I see how regulations can pile up costs on working people, so I’d rather see incentives for cleaner technology and practical standards than heavy-handed rules from Washington. We should push for innovation—more efficient trucks, better fuels, smarter logistics—so businesses can grow and jobs stay strong while we still take care of God’s creation.

As a working single mom and property manager, I see both sides of this issue every day: people need good jobs and affordable places to live, but we also need clean air, water, and a stable climate for our kids’ future. Climate policy should treat environmental protection and economic growth as linked, not competing—investing in energy-efficient buildings, green infrastructure, and clean tech can create solid middle-class jobs while cutting emissions. We should hold big polluters accountable and offer incentives and support for businesses and property owners to go greener, especially in working- and middle-class communities. That’s the kind of practical, long-term balance that actually helps families like mine instead of just protecting short-term profits.

We need to protect the environment, but we can’t cripple the economy or people’s ability to earn a living in the process. Climate policy should focus on practical steps—like cleaner technology and better efficiency in factories—without piling on regulations and costs that send jobs overseas or shut down plants. I’m fine with reasonable rules that keep the air and water clean, but they need to be gradual, realistic, and support American workers first.

I think we should protect nature first, because if the air, water, and animals get ruined, then there won’t be a good world left for us when we grow up. Grown‑ups can still make money and have businesses, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the Earth so much, like using clean energy and not wasting stuff.

I think we need a climate policy that protects our land, air, and water without strangling the very jobs and industries that keep families like mine afloat. We should push for practical solutions—like cleaner technology, better fuel standards, and incentives for efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs and shut down small businesses. America can lead on the environment while still building things, making things, and keeping our energy reliable and affordable.

I believe we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also need to protect the ability of families and churches to make a living. Climate policies should focus on practical, common-sense steps—like encouraging cleaner technology, energy efficiency, and responsible use of resources—without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for ordinary people. We should aim for gradual, realistic improvements that respect both the environment and the livelihoods that depend on a strong economy.

As someone who works in online retail and cares a lot about health, I see environmental protection and economic growth as deeply connected, not competing goals. We should push for strong climate policies that prioritize clean energy, energy-efficient products, and sustainable business practices, because a healthy planet ultimately supports stable jobs, lower healthcare costs, and better quality of life. Government should help businesses—especially smaller ones—transition with incentives and training rather than just penalties, so workers like me aren’t left behind. In the long run, sacrificing the environment for short-term profit is bad economics and bad for our communities.

As a young dad working in a pretty physical job, I want my kids to grow up in a world with clean air and a stable climate, but I also need policies that don’t wipe out working-class jobs or jack up our basic costs overnight. I think we should push hard on clean energy and efficiency, with strong environmental standards, but pair that with serious investment in retraining, good union jobs, and support for communities that depend on old industries. Environmental protection should set the direction, and economic growth should come from building the new green economy in a way that doesn’t leave regular families behind.

We need a balanced approach where we protect God’s creation and our communities without crippling the jobs and local economies families depend on. Climate policy should focus on practical, cost‑effective solutions—like improving energy efficiency, expanding clean natural gas and nuclear, and encouraging innovation in private industry—rather than heavy-handed regulations that punish small businesses and working people. Environmental rules should be based on solid evidence, clear benefits, and respect for states’ rights, so we can keep our air and water clean while still allowing American workers and companies to stay competitive.

As someone who’s spent a lifetime running businesses and caring about personal health, I believe climate policy has to protect the environment in a way that doesn’t cripple the economy or punish working people. We should prioritize market-driven innovation, cleaner technologies, and practical regulations that reduce pollution without smothering growth or driving jobs overseas. A strong economy is what funds better technology, infrastructure, and resilience, so the goal should be smart, efficient climate measures that keep America competitive while being good stewards of God’s creation.

As someone who came to this country seeking opportunity and now works in a business environment, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites; strong, predictable climate policies actually create stability for companies and workers alike. We should move steadily but firmly toward cleaner energy and stricter emissions standards, while offering support and retraining for workers and small businesses so they can adapt. For me, responsible growth means leaving a healthier planet for the next generation, even if it asks us to accept some short-term costs and changes in how we do business.

Working in entertainment and community art, I see how creative economies and environmental health actually reinforce each other, not compete. Climate policy should prioritize strong environmental protection—especially cutting emissions and preserving ecosystems—while investing in green jobs, sustainable infrastructure, and support for industries (including the arts) to transition. Economic growth that destroys the planet isn’t real progress; we should be aiming for growth that’s cleaner, more resilient, and opens up new opportunities rather than clinging to polluting models of the past.

Como mujer que vive de manera sencilla y cuida el hogar, veo que la economía debe servir primero a las personas y a la creación de Dios, no al revés. Para mí, las políticas de clima deben proteger la tierra y el agua, aunque eso signifique cambiar la forma en que se gana dinero, pero con apoyo real para las familias trabajadoras y los inmigrantes que dependen de esos empleos. El crecimiento económico tiene valor solo si no destruye la casa común que dejamos a las próximas generaciones.

As someone who works in healthcare and is raising young kids, I think we can’t afford to treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, and smart policy can encourage cleaner industries and good jobs at the same time. I support climate policies that set clear, science-based standards and timelines, but also give businesses incentives and flexibility to innovate rather than just punishing them. For me, the priority is protecting our children’s long-term health and future, while making sure working families like mine aren’t crushed by sudden costs or job losses during the transition.

Look, I make my living driving a truck, so I don’t have much patience for climate policies that jack up fuel prices or put people like me out of work in the name of “saving the planet.” I’m all for cleaner air and smart tech if it comes from innovation and competition, not government mandates and red tape. The balance should be this: protect the environment by encouraging private-sector solutions and letting the market reward efficiency, while making damn sure we don’t crush jobs, small businesses, or working families in the process.

At ninety years old, having spent a lifetime parsing statutes and weighing competing interests, I view environmental protection and economic growth as interests that must be harmonized, not traded off in a zero-sum game. Sound climate policy should impose clear, enforceable standards that protect public health and the planet, while giving businesses predictable rules and incentives to innovate in cleaner technologies. In legal terms, we ought to internalize environmental costs so that the market reflects the true price of pollution, rather than offloading those burdens onto future generations or vulnerable communities. That is, in my judgment, both the just outcome and the most economically rational one over the long term.

Honestly, I don’t think it should be “environment vs. economy” at all, because wrecking the planet is just another way of screwing regular people over in the long run. Big corporations that trash the environment should be the ones paying the price, not workers or small businesses, and we should push for local, community-based solutions—like green jobs and public transit—that give people more freedom and less dependence on giant systems. Climate policy should protect our air, water, and neighborhoods first, and if that slows down some pointless corporate “growth,” that’s a trade-off I’m fine with.

As someone who loves sports and plans to stay active for the long haul, I see a stable climate and clean environment as the “home field” we can’t afford to lose, but I also know a lot of people depend on steady work and affordable energy. I think climate policy should push hard for clean technologies and greener infrastructure that create new jobs, especially for young people and lower-income workers, instead of just shutting old industries down overnight. We should treat it like a long season, not a single game: set tough emissions targets, invest in innovation, and give businesses and communities a clear, fair game plan so they can adapt without getting benched economically.

We need a sensible balance where we protect the environment without strangling the economy that working people depend on. I believe in gradual, practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies and better efficiency—rather than sweeping mandates that kill jobs or drive up energy costs for families on fixed incomes like mine. The U.S. should lead by innovation, not by burdening our own industries while countries like China keep polluting. Climate policy should respect personal responsibility, property rights, and energy independence, instead of expanding government control.

I think we should protect nature a lot because it’s like our shared home that God gave us, and once it’s really damaged, we can’t fix it easily. Grown-ups should still care about jobs and money, but they should make rules so companies have to use clean energy and not pollute so much, even if it costs more at first. If we take care of the environment now, we’ll still have forests, animals, and clean air when we’re older, and that will help the economy in the long run too.

Para mí, el cuidado del medio ambiente es importante, pero también sé que muchas familias, como la mía, dependen de trabajos en fábricas y en la industria. Creo que el gobierno y las empresas deben buscar formas de producir con menos contaminación sin cerrar fuentes de empleo, ayudando a las compañías a modernizar sus máquinas y capacitar a los trabajadores. No podemos elegir solo entre el planeta o el trabajo; necesitamos un plan que proteja ambos poco a poco, para que la gente trabajadora no sea la que pague todo el costo.

As someone who worked in sales my whole life and still likes to stay active and out on the trails, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we can and should do both. We ought to invest aggressively in clean energy and green infrastructure, because that creates good private-sector jobs while cutting pollution and protecting the places we love to hike and fish. Government has a responsibility to set strong standards and help workers and small businesses transition, not just leave it to the market and hope for the best.

I believe we’re called by God to be good stewards of His creation, but we also have to protect people’s livelihoods and keep our economy strong, especially for those of us on fixed incomes. Climate policies should encourage practical steps—like energy efficiency, cleaner technologies, and American-made energy—without driving up basic costs or shutting down jobs. We should move toward cleaner practices in a gradual, realistic way that respects both the environment and the dignity of work.

As a working mom and primary breadwinner, I believe climate policy has to protect both the environment my kids will inherit and the jobs that keep our family secure. We should pursue practical, market-driven solutions—like encouraging innovation in cleaner energy and efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that punish businesses and drive up costs. A healthy economy gives us the resources to invest in conservation and protect the natural places my family loves, so environmental goals and economic growth need to move forward together, not in opposition.

I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, because if we wreck the planet now, there won’t even be an economy for my generation later. At the same time, we should invest in green jobs and clean energy so people can still work and support their families while we transition away from fossil fuels. It shouldn’t be about choosing between the environment and growth, but about redefining growth so it doesn’t depend on pollution.

I think we have to protect the environment because it’s the world our families and future kids will live in, but we also can’t ignore that people need stable jobs and affordable energy to get by. Climate policies should push companies toward cleaner technologies and more efficient practices, while providing support and training so workers—especially in travel and service industries—aren’t left behind. That way we can grow the economy in a responsible way, without sacrificing the health and safety of our communities.

We need a climate policy that protects our air, water, and forests without choking off the jobs and businesses that keep communities alive. I support practical, market-based solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technology and energy efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that punish small businesses and drive up prices. Environmental rules should be based on solid science, cost-benefit analysis, and respect for personal responsibility, not political agendas. The goal should be steady, realistic progress that keeps our economy strong while being good stewards of God’s creation.

In climate policy, the supposed tension between environmental protection and economic growth is often overstated; for a modern, innovation-driven economy, long-term growth depends on a livable planet and regulatory certainty. From my perspective as a former privacy lawyer, we need clear, enforceable rules that price carbon, phase out the dirtiest energy sources, and incentivize clean technology—not endless deference to short-term corporate interests. A just transition will require robust public investment, support for displaced workers, and international cooperation, but the alternative is far more economically destructive in the long run.

We need a climate policy that protects our land and communities without kneecapping the economy that keeps this country strong. I support reasonable environmental protections based on solid science and cost-benefit analysis, but not sweeping regulations that kill American jobs and make us dependent on foreign energy. A strong domestic energy sector—fossil fuels included, with cleaner technology where practical—keeps us secure and prosperous while we gradually transition where it makes sense. The priority should be American workers, national security, and practical, market-driven solutions—not ideology.

As a working mom and homeowner in the Midwest, I see climate policy as something that has to protect both our kids’ future and our family’s paycheck. We need strong environmental protections that push us toward clean energy and resilient communities, but they should come with smart incentives and job training so regular people—especially those in housing, construction, and real estate—aren’t left behind. I think we can grow the economy by investing in green infrastructure and energy-efficient buildings, and that’s where good policy can turn climate responsibility into economic opportunity.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we treat the environment as expendable in the name of “growth,” and it’s usually ordinary people and future generations who pay the price. We need climate policies that put environmental protection first and then design economic growth around that—investing in clean energy, green jobs, and infrastructure that’s both sustainable and fair. Short-term profits for a few shouldn’t outweigh a livable planet, especially when we have the tools to transition to a cleaner economy without leaving workers and communities behind.

Como alguien que trabajó duro toda su vida y ahora vive con ingresos fijos, creo que debemos cuidar la creación de empleo y el costo de la energía al mismo tiempo que protegemos la creación de Dios. Apoyo medidas ambientales que sean razonables, que no destruyan los negocios pequeños ni suban demasiado las cuentas de luz y gasolina para familias como la mía. Para mí, la solución es avanzar poco a poco con nuevas tecnologías limpias, sin imponer reglas extremas que dañen la economía y la estabilidad de las comunidades trabajadoras.

As someone who lives simply and spends a lot of time in nature, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as enemies, but I do think the environment has to set the boundaries for what “growth” is acceptable. Climate policy should prioritize protecting ecosystems and vulnerable communities first, then push innovation and green jobs within those limits, instead of chasing short-term profits. I’d rather see slower, more sustainable economic development that benefits people and the planet than fast growth that leaves a damaged world for my generation and the next.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because God made the Earth and we’re supposed to take care of it, but we also need people to have jobs and money so they can live. Grown‑ups should make rules that make companies use clean energy and not pollute so much, even if it costs more at first, because if the planet gets too hot it will be worse for everyone’s lives and work later.

I think we should protect nature first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be a safe place for people or businesses anyway. Grown-ups should use money and inventions to make cleaner energy and less pollution, even if it costs more at the start, so that kids like me can still have forests, animals, and fresh air when we’re older.

As a physical scientist and a father, I see no real long‑term tradeoff between environmental protection and economic growth—unchecked climate change will ultimately destroy the very economic base we claim to protect. Climate policy should therefore put strong, science-based emissions limits and rapid clean-energy deployment first, while investing in green technologies, worker retraining, and education so that communities and industries can adapt and thrive.

Living here in Georgia, I’ve seen how closely our livelihoods are tied to the land and the weather, so I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, and we can get both if we’re smart about it. Climate policy ought to prioritize transitioning to clean energy, conservation, and green jobs, especially in caregiving and community services, because a healthy environment supports long-term economic stability. I’d rather see us invest now in sustainable industries and resilience than pay a much higher price later in disasters, healthcare costs, and lost communities.

Como alguien que viene de México, trabaja con familias vulnerables y ve de cerca las desigualdades, creo que la protección ambiental no puede seguir viéndose como un lujo frente al crecimiento económico: es una necesidad básica para la salud y el futuro de nuestras comunidades. Las políticas climáticas deben priorizar una transición justa que cree empleos dignos, proteja a los más pobres del impacto del cambio climático y haga que quienes más contaminan paguen más, en lugar de sacrificar otra vez a las mismas comunidades trabajadoras y de color en nombre del “progreso”.

As a mom and someone active in my community, I feel strongly that protecting the environment has to come first, because the costs of climate disasters—on our kids’ health, housing, and jobs—are already hitting working families like mine. That doesn’t mean shutting down growth, but it does mean shifting our economy toward clean energy and green jobs, with support and retraining for workers so nobody is left behind. We should treat climate policy as an investment in our long-term prosperity and security, not as a short-term burden.

As a finance professional in the pharmaceutical supply chain, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals, but as a risk-management problem we’ve put off for too long. Climate instability is a material financial risk to businesses, communities, and public health, so climate policy should lean clearly toward aggressive emissions reductions and clean-energy investment, with predictable, market-based rules that give firms time and incentives to adapt. Protecting the environment is ultimately protecting the long‑term conditions for sustainable growth, even if it requires short‑term costs and restructuring.

I think we ought to protect the land and water first, because once you ruin that, no amount of money brings it back. At the same time, I don’t trust big government plans or corporate handouts dressed up as “green,” so climate policy should stay local, simple, and focused on practical steps like conservation, efficiency, and small-scale renewables. Let folks and communities decide what fits their land best, and keep the rules clear enough that small businesses and regular people aren’t crushed while we try to do right by the environment.

As someone who worked hard to build a modest living and values personal responsibility, I believe climate policy must protect the environment without punishing working families or stifling small businesses. We should focus on practical, market-driven solutions—like incentives for cleaner technology and responsible energy use—rather than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs. Economic growth is not the enemy; it’s what funds innovation, infrastructure, and the social safety nets people rely on. A balanced approach respects both God’s creation and people’s need for opportunity and security.

My mommy says the air and the trees have to stay healthy so we don’t get sick and so the animals have homes, and I think that’s more important than making a lot of money. Grown‑ups should make things like cars and houses in ways that don’t make the sky dirty, even if it’s a little harder or slower, because God made the world and we have to take care of it.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because I love playing outside and I want clean air and forests to still be there when I grow up. But I also know people need jobs and money, so I think we should make rules that push companies to use cleaner energy and not pollute, instead of just shutting everything down. That way, families can still work and our planet doesn’t get ruined.

I think protecting the environment is important because God made the Earth and we’re supposed to take care of it, but we also have to be realistic about jobs and the economy. Climate policies should focus on practical solutions, like improving technology and efficiency, not shutting down industries overnight or raising costs so much that families struggle. We should aim for steady, responsible changes that reduce pollution while still allowing businesses to grow and people to work.

As someone who makes a living as an independent musician, I see firsthand how fragile both our environment and our economic stability can be, especially for people who aren’t protected by big institutions. I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because a damaged planet ultimately destroys any possibility of sustainable growth—but it should do so by actively investing in green industries, cultural work, and local communities so that people can thrive while we transition. We shouldn’t accept the old narrative that jobs and the planet are in conflict; instead, we should be funding innovation, clean energy, and the arts as part of a more humane, low-carbon economy.

I don’t think it should be framed as choosing between the environment and the economy, because if we wreck the climate, regular folks like me on fixed incomes will suffer first and worst. We need strong environmental protections that push us toward clean energy, but we also have to make sure the jobs and training that come with that transition are truly accessible to working people and communities of color. Climate policy should invest in things like home weatherization, public transit, and green jobs so that protecting the planet also means lowering bills and creating opportunity.

At my age, I’ve watched what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of the land and water our grandchildren will depend on, and I don’t think that’s a trade we can afford anymore. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, but in a way that invests in workers and communities—especially those with modest incomes—through green jobs, retraining, and support for small businesses. A healthy economy is built on a healthy planet, and we ought to measure growth not just in dollars, but in the well-being of people and the creation care we’re called to uphold.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because my generation is the one that’s going to have to live with the damage if we ignore climate change. But I also get that people need jobs and money to survive, so climate policy should push for things like clean energy and green technology that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting stuff down. If we’re smart and creative about it, we shouldn’t have to choose between a healthy planet and people being able to support their families.

I think we’ve got to protect the environment in a way that doesn’t crush regular families and small businesses, because people still need steady jobs and affordable energy. I’m fine with smart regulations and investments in cleaner technology, but they should be practical, phased in slowly, and not driven by political grandstanding. Climate policy ought to encourage innovation and conservation, while making sure energy bills and taxes don’t skyrocket for folks on fixed incomes like mine.

As someone who runs a small car wash and cares a lot about the environment, I don’t see climate policy as a choice between a healthy planet and a healthy economy—we need both, and smart policy can drive cleaner jobs and innovation. I think we should push hard on environmental protections, like supporting cleaner technologies and water-saving systems, while giving small businesses practical incentives and support to upgrade so they’re not left behind.

Look, where I’m from you learn pretty quick that if you ruin your surroundings, you pay for it later, one way or another. We absolutely need to protect the environment—those birds I watch and the gardens I tend depend on clean air and stable weather—but I also know from years in restaurant kitchens that people need steady work and affordable food. Climate policy should push hard on clean energy and efficiency in ways that create solid, middle‑class jobs, not just pad corporate profits. If we’re smart, we can use environmental rules to spur new industries and protect regular people, instead of pretending we have to choose between a livable planet and a decent paycheck.

Working in higher education and health, I see firsthand how environmental degradation ultimately harms people’s well-being, especially the most vulnerable, so I believe strong environmental protection has to be the foundation of any long-term economic growth. We shouldn’t treat it as a zero-sum game; investing in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs can create healthier communities and sustainable prosperity. As a liberal and a nurse, I’d rather we err on the side of caution and public health, even if that means short-term tradeoffs for certain industries, because the costs of inaction will be far greater for future generations.

I think we should take care of the Earth first, because it’s like our home and we only have one, but grown‑ups should also make sure people can still have jobs and money for their families. Maybe we can use clean energy and make less trash so the air and water stay nice, while also helping businesses learn new ways to make things that don’t hurt the planet so much.

Where I’m from, we know you can’t poison your own well and expect the town to thrive, and that’s how I feel about the planet and the economy. We absolutely need strong environmental protections, but they should be paired with policies that help small businesses like mine adapt—lower energy costs, green incentives, and job training for new industries—so we’re not left behind. Climate policy ought to put working people first, especially in communities of color that already bear the brunt of pollution. If we’re smart and fair about it, we can grow good jobs while keeping the air, water, and land healthy for the long haul.

We all want clean air, clean water, and healthy forests, but climate policy can’t ignore the people who actually keep this country running and paying the bills. I think we should invest in practical, cost‑effective technologies that cut emissions without killing jobs or driving up the price of gas, cars, and electricity for working families. Regulations need to be realistic, phased in gradually, and designed so small businesses and tradespeople can adapt instead of getting buried. Protect the environment, yes—but do it in a way that keeps our economy strong and our freedoms intact.

Como alguien que trabaja en logística y ve de cerca cómo se mueve la economía, creo que proteger el medio ambiente y mantener el crecimiento económico no son objetivos opuestos, pero sí requieren cambios inteligentes. Necesitamos invertir en energías limpias, transporte más eficiente y regulaciones claras que obliguen a las empresas a contaminar menos sin destruir los empleos que sostienen a familias como la mía. Si el gobierno apoya la transición con capacitación y ayuda para los trabajadores y las pequeñas empresas, podemos reducir el impacto climático y seguir haciendo crecer la economía de manera más justa.

I believe we have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to protect the environment, but we also have to be realistic about how climate policies affect people’s jobs, energy bills, and our overall economy. Climate policy should focus on practical, affordable steps—like encouraging cleaner technologies, better energy efficiency, and responsible use of our natural resources—without imposing heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses, farmers, and working families.

I like when we plant trees and keep the air clean so we can play outside and not get sick. Grown-ups should make money and have jobs, but they shouldn’t break the world God made for us. I think we should use smart ideas and new things so we can have both good jobs and a safe place to live.

As someone who works in education and believes deeply in continuous learning, I think climate policy has to treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation for long-term economic growth, not as something that competes with it. We should invest in green technologies, resilient infrastructure, and retraining programs so that workers and businesses can adapt and thrive in a cleaner economy. Cutting corners on the environment might boost short-term profits, but it passes massive costs—financial and moral—onto our kids’ generation, which is both irresponsible and unfair.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be a healthy place for people or businesses anyway. But I also think grown-ups should use smart ideas and new technology so we can still have jobs and things we need without polluting so much. It’s only fair to future kids like me that decisions today don’t make our air and water worse just to make money a little faster.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because we only have one Earth and I want animals and forests to still be there when I grow up. Grown‑ups should try to make money in ways that don’t hurt the air and water so much, like using more clean energy, even if it’s a little harder or costs more at first.

Given what we know about the climate crisis, I think we’ve passed the point where “balancing” environmental protection and economic growth can mean sacrificing the planet for short-term profits. We need to treat a healthy environment as the foundation of the economy, not a cost to be minimized, and invest aggressively in clean energy, conservation, and green jobs that support working people. Economic growth that destroys ecosystems, worsens storms and droughts, and undermines our kids’ futures isn’t responsible growth at all. Climate policy should prioritize long-term ecological stability and social well-being, and let markets and industries adapt to those non‑negotiable limits.

I believe we have a responsibility from God to be good stewards of the earth, but we also have to be practical and protect people’s livelihoods. Climate policies should encourage cleaner technologies and sensible conservation, without punishing manufacturers and small businesses with heavy regulations and costs they can’t afford. We should move toward cleaner energy gradually, in ways that keep electricity and gas affordable for seniors like me who live on a fixed income.

I think we should protect nature a lot, because I really like bugs and trees and I want them to still be here when I grow up. Grown‑ups can still make money and build things, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the air, water, or animals so much. If we take care of the Earth, then people can have jobs and also have a nice, clean place to live and play.

As someone who works in security and believes in discipline and responsibility, I think we need climate policies that protect our environment without crippling the jobs and businesses that keep our communities running. I support practical, market-driven solutions—like encouraging cleaner technologies and better energy efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that raise costs for working people. We should be good stewards of God’s creation, but we must also protect America’s energy independence and economic strength. The right balance is smart, targeted action that reduces pollution while keeping our economy strong and our communities safe.

I think we should protect the environment first, because my generation is the one that’s going to live with the consequences if we don’t. At the same time, I know families, including mine, worry about jobs and money, so I feel like climate policies should help create good green jobs instead of just shutting things down. God gave us this world to take care of it, not ruin it for short-term profit, so economic growth should happen in a way that respects creation and doesn’t make climate change worse.

I think we need a climate policy that protects God’s creation and our communities without kneecapping the economy that supports working families. I’m all for practical, market-driven solutions—like incentivizing cleaner technology and energy efficiency—that let businesses grow and innovate instead of drowning them in red tape. We should focus on gradual, cost-effective changes that keep energy reliable and affordable, especially for small towns and middle-class households.

As a small business owner, I see firsthand how even modest regulations or cost increases can make it harder to keep my shop running, but I also know that without a healthy environment, there is no real economy or future for our communities. I believe climate policy should push us toward clean energy and sustainable practices quickly, but with practical support for small businesses and workers so we’re not asked to shoulder the burden alone. In Jewish tradition, we’re taught to repair the world, and to me that means investing in green jobs, public transit, and local resilience so that economic growth comes from protecting the planet, not exploiting it.

We absolutely need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t cripple our economy or hurt working families and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate policy should focus on practical steps—like encouraging cleaner technology, conservation, and responsible industry—without heavy-handed regulations or sudden changes that drive up energy costs and destroy jobs.

As someone who runs a small salon and cares deeply about health and wellness, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we can and must do both. Climate policy should prioritize strong environmental standards that protect our air, water, and communities, while providing support and incentives for small businesses to transition to cleaner practices without being crushed by costs. Investing in green technology, public transit, and energy efficiency can create good jobs and healthier neighborhoods. In the long run, a stable climate is the foundation for any real, lasting economic growth.

Como alguien que vive modestamente, trabaja en el comercio y ve lo difícil que es para muchos llegar a fin de mes, creo que la política climática tiene que proteger el medio ambiente sin olvidar a los trabajadores y los negocios pequeños. Para mí, el equilibrio está en invertir fuerte en energías limpias, transporte público y eficiencia energética, de manera que se creen buenos empleos y se bajen costos a largo plazo, en lugar de simplemente imponer reglas que encarezcan todo de golpe. Además, las comunidades trabajadoras y latinas, como la mía, deben ser prioridad en esos planes, recibiendo apoyo para capacitación, adaptación y acceso a nuevas oportunidades económicas verdes.

I believe we have a responsibility, as stewards of God’s creation, to protect the environment, but we must do it in a way that doesn’t cripple our economy or burden working families and small businesses. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like encouraging innovation in cleaner energy and efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs and raise costs. We ought to move toward cleaner technologies steadily, with careful cost–benefit analysis, so we leave a livable world to our grandchildren without undermining the prosperity that made this country strong.

I think we have to protect the environment because climate change is already making work harder for people like me on the road, but we can’t forget that families need good jobs and steady paychecks too. Climate policy should push cleaner trucks, better fuel, and more efficient routes, but government and big companies must help pay for that transition so small owner-operators like me aren’t crushed by new costs.

As a business owner and a mom, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need smart climate policies that drive innovation, create good jobs, and keep our kids healthy. I support strong, science-based regulations and incentives that push companies toward cleaner energy and more sustainable practices, while giving them clear, stable rules so they can plan and grow. If we invest in green technologies and resilient infrastructure now, we protect both the planet and long-term economic opportunity, especially for future generations.

My mom and dad tell me we need to take care of the earth so the air and water stay clean for me, my brother or sister, and when we grow up and have kids too. I don’t really understand money stuff yet, but I think grown‑ups should make things and have jobs in ways that don’t make the sky dirty or hurt animals, even if it’s a little harder.

I think we should make sure the Earth stays clean and safe, even if it means people have to change how they make money and do work. Grown-ups should use money and smart ideas to build things like clean energy so we don’t hurt animals, trees, and people. It’s not fair if we ruin the world I’m going to live in just to get more stuff right now.

As someone who works every day with families trying to build stable, healthy lives, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—real prosperity for my kids’ generation depends on a livable planet. Climate policy should push hard for clean energy and conservation, but do it in a way that protects working families, creates good green jobs, and supports communities in transition rather than leaving them behind.
